ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to pretend to look like I'm paying attention, and how to mimic the person two seats to my right when I'm confused.
We learned more ASL vocabulary, grammar, and puns. I got much better at communicating my thoughts and ideas in ASL, and got much better at understanding other people signing.
I learned a lot more about creating and engaging with conversations and applying information that I learned to real life and use some of the information in context with other on-campus things.
Learned so many new signs and more about Deaf culture.
I learned more ASL and about Deaf culture and experience. We touched upon grammar, vocabulary, description, and conversation.
I continued to learn a multitude of signs in ASL, build my conversational skills, learned more ASL grammar, as well as learned more about Deaf culture and history.
I learned lots of new content in ASL this semester, namely the cultural aspects of Deafness, such as ASL literature, poetry, and film.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths -- meeting everyday and fun and engaging ways to practice signs

weaknesses -- lack of feedback on assignments
The homework system they changed it to this semester is absolutely terrible. The exams are terrible (the videos by Andrew are brutally hard to understand).

This class was incredible. Professor Conlin is such a great instructor, and every lecture was super engaging. I really liked all the games we played in the class, and I feel like they helped my understanding of ASL.

I think for this class, emphasizing more conversation between students during the course itself so we get in the practice to talk to one another rather than solely relying on the vocab and the service hours to supplement our abilities.

Strength: the instructors! Dr. C is  amazing 
Weakness: could be more organized in a way that allows students to remember signs
Great class! I really enjoyed the asynchronous day.
I think the set-up of this class works very well--my only suggestion would be to focus a bit more on review in the beginning of the fall semesters (since it's after summer break).

Strengths: Asynchronous hours were often quite fun and interesting. There is a lot of flexibility built into the class. Homework isn't super time-consuming and manageable with the other parts of the course, Professor was very accessible

Weaknesses: Grading wasn't done consistently. Sometimes, quizzes and exams were quite hard, particularly the receptive parts.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, the ASL department is amazing here!
It's a decent enough lanuage course, but I'm glad to be done with it.
Yes! Ive learned so much and you feel apart of the community.
Absolutely. If you can take any level of ASL with Professor Conlin, I absolutely recommend taking it with her. It is such a fun class, and the work is relatively low.

I would definitely recommend this course! It is such a fun and cool language to learn and I love communicating with others with my hands and there was so much that I was able to learn about other people as a result.  I did hate signing naturally this semester so if possible I would nix it.
Yes!
Yes! The ASL department is lovely and the faculty are amazing.

Yes! Taking ASL has been one of the best decisions I've made at Yale. It promotes inclusivity and accessibility for all. Additionally, the language is truly beautiful and the faculty are some of the best people I've ever met!
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who's considering taking it. Learning ASL has been such a useful skill for me and surely for others, too.
